docs.lead_paragraph: Guests at the Opera House Hotel have mostly been unfazed by the building’s link to the worst spreading of Legionnaires’ disease in New York City’s history.

headline.main: Brisk Business at Bronx Hotel, Center of Legionnaires’ Outbreak
headline.print_headline: A Hotel Avoids Vacancies, and Stigma, After an Outbreak

docs.abstract: Opera House Hotel in South Bronx has not seen dip in business since its cooling tower was proven to be source of Legionnaires' outbreak that killed 12 and sickened over 120 people; continually high occupancy rates reflect how few guests are either not aware or unconcerned about disease.
docs.snippet: Guests at the Opera House Hotel have mostly been unfazed by the building’s link to the worst spreading of Legionnaires’ disease in New York City’s history.

docs.lead_paragraph: Advocates for patients have urged federal officials to guide state Medicaid directors on appropriate coverage of the drugs, including one that can cost up to $1,000 a pill.

headline.main: White House Is Pressed to Help Widen Access to Hepatitis C Drugs via Medicaid
headline.print_headline: White House Is Pressed to Help Widen Access to Hepatitis C Drugs via Medicaid

docs.abstract: Health care advisory council says Medicaid officials should increase access to prescription drugs for hepatitis C, including drugs that cost up to $1,000 a pill; also criticizes state restrictions on drugs, noting many are inconsistent with standard treatment guidelines.
docs.snippet: Advocates for patients have urged federal officials to guide state Medicaid directors on appropriate coverage of the drugs, including one that can cost up to $1,000 a pill.

docs.lead_paragraph: Suspicions about end-of-life options remain strong among many African-Americans. Some doctors and clergy members are going to church to reshape views.

headline.main: A Racial Gap in Attitudes Toward Hospice Care
headline.print_headline: A Racial Divide on Hospice Care

docs.abstract: Black Americans are far more resistant to hospice care and advance care directives than whites, tending instead to choose aggressive life-sustaining interventions for seriously ill loved ones; doctors and clergy members are working to change attitude rooted in deep distrust of medical system and, for some, religious conviction.
docs.snippet: Suspicions about end-of-life options remain strong among many African-Americans. Some doctors and clergy members are going to church to reshape views.

keywords.value: Living Wills and Health Care Proxies
